sigmajs for R

With the rise in popularity of networks, it is important for R users to have access to a package that allows visualising the aforementioned networks in a highly configurable, interactive and dynamic manner. `sigmajs` leverages the original library's great many methods by providing numerous proxies, buttons to trigger events, and more.


Get Started

Get started with sigmajs , draw your first graphs and learn about settings.

Start Layouts

Dynamism

Learn how to make a temporal graph in static R markdown documents.

Dynamic Buttons

Animate

Animate the color, size, and x/y coordinates of the nodes on the canvas.

Animate

Shiny

Explore the package's proxies and learn how to capture user interactions.

Guide Demo

Crosstalk

Have sigmajs play hand-in-hand with other htmlwidgets, highlight nodes and neighbours on click.

Crosstalk

Formats

Build sigmajs graphs from igraph objects or GEXF files in a single function call.

igraph GEXF

sigmajs is part of the twinetverse, a set of packages for Twitter network analysis and visualisation: it'll get you started with network data and walk you through advanced uses of sigmajs.

Twinetverse new

The twinetverse is a set of packages, including sigmajs, to visualise Twitter interactions:

  1. Data collection
  2. Data processing
  3. Visualisation

The twinetverse comes with an in-depth guide: a 12 chapter-long book filled with examples. It is highly recommended if you want to fully grasp the intricacies of sigmajs. The book will get you setup and running with network data if you are unfamiliar with it.
Website Book

Install

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("JohnCoene/sigmajs") # github
devtools::install_bitbucket("JohnCoene/sigmajs") # bitbucket

Example

Most functions have corresponding demo().

Note that the graphs do not work in the RStudio viewer, and thus open in your default browser.

library(sigmajs)

# generate data
nodes <- sg_make_nodes(25) # 20 nodes
edges <- sg_make_edges(nodes, 50) # 50 edges

sigmajs() %>% # initialise
  sg_nodes(nodes, id, label, size) %>% # add nodes
  sg_edges(edges, id, source, target) %>% # add edges
  sg_layout() %>%  # layout
  sg_cluster() %>% # cluster
  sg_neighbours() # show node neighbours on node click

Demos

Most functions have corresponding demos, execute the command in the run column to see sigmajs in action. You can also see some of these examples here.

sigmajs demos
name run
add-node demo('add-node', package='sigmajs')
